The tendency to complain is habitual and opportunistic. There is also definitely something in general human nature that causes this to happen. For example………If poor unsuspecting person #1 shows any measure of sympathy or commiserating body language, the complainer will file a subconscious mental cookie and return to the scene of the crime to assail the poor unsuspecting person #1 time and again with cracked pearls of unwanted opinions, theories and sometimes even paranoid delusional musings. Short of offering a clinically approved meds dispenser at the opening of one’s work cube, there is no polite and effective way to deal with the complainer, once said cookie is firmly established in complainer’s psyche. I imagine some crime scene tape and a nice chalk outline might deter the complainer, especially if they also suffer from A.D.D, but it will not solve the long-term problem. Poor unsuspecting person #1 can sometimes be unjustly lumped in with complainer’s destructive deeds, as well…guilt by association. Should the complainee come into certain confidences and over-hear or learn of the complainer’s antics, taking note of the quantity of time complainer spends with poor unsuspecting person #1, then the resulting raised eyebrows and angry looks will catapult poor unsuspecting person #1’s general mood and even affect their work flow. As a defense mechanism and for possible consideration as an overall treatment of CETCS (Chronic Exposure To Complainers Syndrome) I recommend mindless Blog chatter.

Spur of the moment meetings are to Cube Life what pop quizzes were in the 9th grade. I’ve made a mental note that, going forward, meetings are not an ideal time to teach myself how to doodle tweety bird. One such meeting was called (with no time to even get a soda) and ideas bounded to and fro. When everyone agreed we were all on the right track, our Cuber CEO dropped his MOAB and said, “Great! Let’s all create our own policy revision listing everything discussed here and meet back tomorrow to compare formats and styles." I immediately kicked my brain into retro-gear and tried to piece together, in some kind of organized rough draft, the bits and pieces I’d actually paid attention to and absorbed........8th day of the month...hurricanes and postal service routed thru Atlanta....6 days from approval, twice a month, I miss my chair in our old conference room........I wonder what happened to the squirrels that used to live at that building.......those are cute sandals.......have to utilize the requirements and guidelines stated earlier.........processing and mailing timelines.... I wonder if Worker’s Comp. accepts A.D.D as a work related disability. It is a very debilitating affliction and I still don’t know how to doodle a tweety.

Out of state contractor's are a very distant consideration. Temporary out of state contractor's even more so. Should this be the way it is? No, not at all. Is it? Yes, very much so. Case in point: Angry contractor calls mellow Cube Life employee (who is very busy blogging and still waking up) and immediately settles into a 10 minute barrage about the postal service, not receiving paychecks promptly, being a single parent, living pay check to pay check and needing direct deposit.......... I am not a single parent, nor do I live paycheck to paycheck but I do get irritated when I give myself a wicked paper cut opening up the envelope that contains my paycheck. Can I use that experience to put me in a place to better help Angry Contractor? No, I tried and it didn't help either one of us. I am compassionate enough to understand where Angry Contractor is coming from. I can even appreciate that Angry Contractor wants to contact everyone in Cube World in a crafty tactic to bring as many people on board as possible. This will ultimately work well in Angry Contractor's favor. The more people the better, especially since West coast muffin's and coffee's haven't kicked in yet. I've noticed that people on the East coast tend to grow impatient waiting for West coast office hours to catch up with their world. This affects how they interact with West coast Cuber's. I wonder if Cube Life would be a much more mellow place if East coaster's just timelined their caffeine intake to directly mirror those in the West coast. Then we could all get worked up about the mailman together.

My puppy finally found a friend in the one place I never thought possible. A duck. Ever since we brought him home he has wildly charged all the other animals with that rev'd up, ears flapping, hopping, bouncing run he has perfected and all the animals look at him like he is demon spawn. Yesterday I wandered out onto the patio and there was my puppy, all crouched down in the grass, squared off with the mallard. My first instinct was to rush out and break up the unauthorized critter formation and head off any possible altercations but I stayed put instead and watched them. Puppy charged duck and duck shrank back a bit but didn't run. Then puppy crouched again and duck charged puppy and puppy shrank back a bit. They did this 3 times before I finally figured out they were playing. For all I know they could have been in some weird animal joust, fighting for control of the back yard, but puppy's wagging tail told me otherwise (unless puppy is too loopy to figure out hostile environments).........you never know. But it looked like fun. The mallard wouldn't play the crouchy-charge game with me though.

Some people care about things outside themselves and then there are those certain people who can’t stand being bothered. Some people want to share happiness and smiles and then there is a “Meanie” who would rather you’d just die and get out of his way. Cube Life, ( which should be a weekly newsletter but is just my lame-a$$ code name for where I work) like everywhere else, suffers from at least one of these mean people. And, as a rule, he just doesn’t get along with anyone unless that person can advance him in some way, help him along, or provide something the meanie needs. However, in Cube Life, we can always hope that the meanie will leave us alone. This is very unlikely since there are flash points and triggers at every corner. Meanie cannot control stress or frustrations in normal, calm ways and must explode on the more docile and pleasant people that he comes into contact with. There is a cure for the meanie though, it’s manners. There is a reason for manners. Contrary to all those old maxims about base social lubricant and such, it’s a simple thing. People who take care when they speak to you are interested in your reaction. They want to avoid alienating you. They want to continue the social transaction. They want to share a mutually beneficial outcome with you. So here’s the earth shattering revelation I wanted to share so badly: stay away from people who don’t put in the extra effort. Don’t talk to people who make light of your efforts to keep peace. Walk away from those who shout that their rights outweigh all other considerations. Learn to tell potentially useful and rewarding people from selfish, inconsiderate people. I’m not suggesting we spend our time tossing people aside based on whether they were nice to us. I’m suggesting we learn to see the difference between people who couldn’t care less about anything but themselves, and those who at least take a moment to listen to what we have to say. It doesn’t matter so much if they like what we say – just that they actually wanted to hear it in the first place.

Do you realize that the only time in our lives when we like to get old is when we're kids? If you're less than 10 years old, you're so excited about aging that you think in fractions. "How old are you?" "I'm four and a half!" You're never thirty-six and a half. You're four and a half, going on five! That's the key. You get into your teens, now they can't hold you back. You jump to the next number, or even a few ahead. "How old are you?" "I'm gonna be 16!" You could be 13, but hey, you're gonna be 16! And then the greatest day of your life . . . you become 21. Even the words sound like a ceremony . . YOU BECOME 21. YESSSS!!! But then you turn 30. Oooohh, what happened there? Makes you sound like bad milk. He TURNED; we had to throw him out. There's no fun now, you're just a sour-dumpling. What's wrong? What's changed? You BECOME 21, you TURN 30, then you're PUSHING 40. Whoa! Put on the brakes, it's all slipping away. Before you know it, you REACH 50 ...and your dreams are gone. But wait!!! You MAKE it to 60. You didn't think you would! So you BECOME 21, TURN 30, PUSH 40, REACH 50 and MAKE it to 60. You've built up so much speed that you HIT 70! After that it's a day-by-day thing; you HIT Wednesday! You get into your 80s and every day is a complete cycle; you HIT lunch; youTURN 4:30; you REACH bedtime. And it doesn't end there. Into the 90's, you start going backwards; "I Was JUST 92." Then a strange thing happens. If you make it over 100, you become a little kid again. "I'm 100 and a half!" :) (G.Carlin)

You are driving down the road in your car on a wild, stormy night, when you pass a bus stop and you see three people waiting for the bus: 1. An old lady who looks as if she is about to die. 2. An old friend who once saved your life. 3. The perfect partner you have been dreaming about. Which one would you choose to offer a ride to, knowing there could only be one passenger in your car? This is a moral/ethical dilemma that was once actually used as part of a job application. You could pick up the old lady, because she is going to die and thus you should save her first. Or you could take the old friend because he once saved your life, and this would be the perfect chance to pay him back. However, you may never be able to find your perfect mate again so you might want topick that person. One possible answer- Give the car keys to my old friend and let him take the lady to the hospital -- thus saving the old lady and giving my friend a chance to be a hero. I would stay behind and wait for the bus with the partner of my dreams

Laughter is contagious as long as you express it in the company of people who are jovial by nature. To those rigid, morose observers, that you may come into contact with, it is a social conundrum of epic proportions. They can't handle unchecked joy and have a tendency to freeze up, in a very painful looking way. Here are (2) tell tale signs to spot the non-jovial natured subjects in your proximity should you find yourself laughing too hard and feel compelled to force personal self control of said mirth If you get a squinty look and a snort/smile head shake - This is a dead give away that the person you've busted a hoot in front of has no concept how to enjoy the moment If you receive a Spock-like eyebrow glare with a head tilt and hear "hmmmmm" - You may want to direct your twinkling, happy bursts toward someone else, they are clearly wasted on the Vulcanator. :)
